questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hormonal therapy

Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. Menorrhagia/heavy menstrual bleeding is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding, >80mL of blood loss, or >8 days of bleeding per menstrual period. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: 72-year-old woman presents with complete uterine prolapse (procidentia) and urinary incontinence. She is sexually inactive, has multiple comorbidities, and wants a short operative time. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

LeFort partial colpocleisis
Explanation: In elderly, non-sexually active patients with comorbidities, an obliterative procedure like LeFort colpocleisis is preferred due to low risk and shorter duration.

questions.text: During post-op rounds, you note one of the patients has developed fever and flank pain. The nurses inform you that her abdominal drain outputs have been consistently high. Which of the following procedures has the highest incidence of the complication suspected here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wertheim’s hysterectomy
The given case scenario is suggestive of ureteric injury. The highest incidence of this complication is seen with Wertheim’s hysterectomy.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl was brought by her mother to the outpatient department with primary amenorrhea. She had normal breast development and pubic hair. On examination, the vagina was blind-ending and the uterus was not palpable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mullerian agenesis
The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea, normal breasts, and pubic hair, with a blind-ending vagina and uterus not palpable, is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with 2 years of primary infertility. Her cycles are regular and she has no history of dysmenorrhea or dyspareunia. She underwent an HSG which showed bilateral tubal patency. Her husband’s semen analysis is normal. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a normal uterus with an antral follicle count (AFC) of 5. Day 3 labs show:
• FSH: 14 IU/L
• LH: 5 IU/L
• AMH: 0.6 ng/mL
What is the most likely cause of infertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Poor ovarian reserve
Explanation:
• AFC < 10 and AMH < 1.0 ng/mL indicate diminished ovarian reserve.
• FSH > 10 IU/L is also suggestive.
• She has regular cycles, normal tubes, and male factor is ruled out — making ovarian reserve the most likely limiting factor.

choices.text: Dual trigger with hCG and GnRH agonist
Coasting until estradiol levels fall, followed by hCG trigger
GnRH agonist trigger in antagonist cycles with frozen embryo transfer
Immediate oocyte retrieval when follicles reach 10 mm

questions.text:
A woman undergoes infertility treatment and her Usg shows follicles bigger than 18 mm and serum E2 level is 3500 pg/ml

Which of the following reduces the risk of OHSS without compromising pregnancy rates in high-risk women?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

GnRH agonist trigger in antagonist cycles with frozen embryo transfer

This approach allows oocyte retrieval while avoiding the risk of OHSS progression due to pregnancy. The GnRH agonist trigger reduces luteinization and VEGF expression, and a freeze-all strategy eliminates endogenous hCG exposure from early pregnancy — both critical in preventing late OHSS.
Option B, although practiced in some cases, still involves hCG exposure, which may still precipitate OHSS if not timed precisely — thus not the most effective strategy compared to Option C.

questions.text: A 27 year old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination breasts were found to be poorly developed, vagina was present. Ultrasound revealed normal uterus but gonads weren’t detected. Further evaluation done showed 46XY karyotype. The most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Swyer’s syndrome
The given clinical scenario of a 46 XY individual with female internal & external genitalia and poorly developed breasts, presenting with primary amenorrhea points towards the diagnosis of sweyer’s syndrome.

choices.text: Start oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.text:
28-year-old woman presents with thin, off-white, malodorous vaginal discharge for 1 week. She denies itching or dyspareunia. On speculum exam, the vaginal walls are mildly erythematous with homogenous discharge. Wet mount shows clue cells, pH of 5.5, and a positive whiff test. She has no urinary symptoms and is currently 9 weeks pregnant. She was treated for asymptomatic BV in her last pregnancy and delivered preterm at 32 weeks.
What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days
Explanation:
• She meets 3/4 Amsel criteria: clue cells, pH >4.5, positive whiff test → diagnosis of BV.
• She is symptomatic and pregnant — treatment is indicated.
• Oral metronidazole 500 mg BID x 7 days is the preferred treatment for symptomatic BV in pregnancy.
• Intravaginal metronidazole gel is less preferred in pregnancy, especially in the first trimester.
• Reassurance is not appropriate due to symptoms and history of preterm birth linked to BV.

choices.text: Vaginal estrogen cream with SSRI for vasomotor symptoms
Tibolone therapy for vasomotor and genitourinary symptoms

questions.text:
56-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms and dyspareunia affecting her quality of life. She is 6 years postmenopausal and has an intact uterus. Her past medical history includes deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 4 years ago, for which she completed anticoagulation. She has a BMI of 29, is normotensive, and her recent mammogram and pelvic ultrasound are normal. She is seeking treatment for symptom relief.
What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vaginal estrogen cream with SSRI for vasomotor symptoms
Explanation:
• She has significant menopausal symptoms, but a history of DVT is a contraindication to systemic HRT (oral or transdermal estrogen).
• Option A & B: Systemic estrogen (even transdermal) is relatively contraindicated in women with prior VTE.
• Option C: Local vaginal estrogen is safe (minimal systemic absorption) for genitourinary symptoms, and SSRIs/SNRIs (e.g., paroxetine, venlafaxine) are effective for vasomotor symptoms — making this the best choice.
• Option D (Tibolone): Contraindicated in women with history of thromboembolic disease.

questions.text: A teenage girl presented with complaints of excessive growth of coarse hair on her jawline and upper lip. Which of the following is the most common cause for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
The given clinical history of excessive growth of coarse hair is suggestive of hirsutism. The most common cause for hirsutism in female patients is polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).

questions.text: An elderly woman who was found to have an ovarian mass underwent staging laparotomy. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of HPE finding shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Serous cystadenocarcinoma
Psammoma bodies are a histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary. They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not denote malignancy.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presents with painless vaginal bleeding for the past 3 days. She reached menopause 10 years ago and is not on hormone replacement therapy. She has no significant medical history, and her last Pap smear (1 year ago) was normal. On speculum examination, there is blood in the vagina but no obvious cervical or vaginal lesion. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an endometrial thickness of 6 mm.
What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perform endometrial biopsy
Explanation:
• Postmenopausal bleeding always warrants investigation.
• Endometrial thickness >4 mm in a postmenopausal woman is abnormal and requires endometrial sampling to rule out hyperplasia or endometrial carcinoma.
• Hysteroscopy (D) is reserved if biopsy is inadequate or focal lesions (polyps) are suspected.
•Observation or hormonal treatment without ruling out malignancy is inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents with complaints of heavy, prolonged menstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. She is hemodynamically stable and not anemic. Pelvic exam is normal. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a normal-sized uterus with no fibroids, and endometrial thickness is 6 mm. She desires uterine preservation, is not planning future pregnancy, and is not keen on surgery. She has no contraindications to hormonal therapy.
Which of the following is the most effective  management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Levonorgestrel intrauterine system (Mirena) insertion
Explanation:
• Mirena is a first-line treatment for heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) in women without structural causes (e.g., fibroids or polyps).
• It reduces menstrual blood loss by up to 90%, provides contraception, and avoids systemic estrogen.
• Oral treatments may be less effective, and endometrial ablation is usually considered after failure of medical management.

questions.text: The CT of a patient with cervical carcinoma revealed a lesion of 6 cm, extending to the upper part of the vagina and parametrium. What Is the stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The stage of cervical carcinoma is II B as it involves the upper part of the vagina and parametrium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia. A hysterectomy was performed, and the specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intramural Fibroid 
The given clinical scenario as well as the specimen suggests that this is a case of leiomyoma uteri or fibroid uterus. The specimen is of a leiomyoma.
